writing_prompt: After her divorce, Judith finds herself navigating a complicated web of relationships: her enigmatic son, his bold wife, and Georgia, the quirky neighbor who might just understand her better than anyone else. What happens when love, family, and self-discovery collide?
story:
I have to call Georgia for help with the air conditioner. “I thought I couldn’t come over this weekend,” she says.

“I don’t think I can lift it by myself.”

“I see.” I can hear her washing dishes. “So I’m allowed to come over if you need something.”

She arrives within five minutes, as I knew she would. Under the brim of her straw hat her eyes are like peas in aspic. She has a dishcloth tucked into a pocket of her jeans. Georgia has never been married, but she is a better version of the wife I used to be. Her grocery lists say six damask plums where I would write fruit.

“Don’t worry,” she says, taking the screen out of the window. “I’ll be gone by the time they get here.”

“Thank you.” I kiss her hand.

“If you want to thank me, invite me to dinner tonight.”

“Maybe,” I say, but we both know I won’t.


Colt arrives in tight jeans and a bolo tie, his father’s old typewriter in his arms. He sets it on the kitchen table.

“You guys can take my room. And yes, I put in the air conditioner.”

“Don’t know how you live without it.” He takes his shoes off before he goes upstairs. That was one of his father’s rules.

I hold the front door open for my daughter-in-law and her suitcase. Her red hair is in a pompadour, left over from last night’s party. When she kisses my cheek I smell coconut pomade.

“I asked him not to bring that,” Vivian says, looking at the typewriter. “He could use a few days off from work.”

“Would you like some juice? I have orange and pineapple.”

“No, thanks. Too much sugar.” Vivian, all hip bones and rib cage, is afraid of sugar.

I wait until she is upstairs before addressing the typewriter.

“Get out,” I tell the well-worn keys. “Get out.”


Nothing that belongs to Oliver is allowed in my house. When he left me I held a tag sale on my front lawn. The first days passed without a single prospect. People were shy. They knew Oliver as the man who spread fireplace ashes on icy steps. They remembered when he cleared the road of tree branches after a hurricane. But I knew I could trust a free market. Was I really selling that guitar for five dollars? I was.

I met Georgia at my sale, over a canvas bag of my wedding china. She’d moved to the neighborhood a year before, and I knew as much about her as did everyone else on our street: she was a spinster who’d made an enormous web of pulled cotton to cover her front windows at Halloween, and at Christmas she left icebox cookies in our mailboxes. She was wearing a souvenir T-shirt from Hollywood, and between her breasts a giant palm tree waved its sequined fronds.

“How much for the china?” she’d said.

“I don’t want anything for that.”

“How much?”

“Zero dollars and zero cents.”

She picked up a tempered-glass paperweight shaped like an abalone shell. “I’ll give you five dollars for this, and no less than fifty for the china.”

I was drinking a beer, which I set aside to count her change. “This isn’t how bargaining usually works,” I said.

“I don’t want to feel like I’m stealing something,” she said.


Colt comes downstairs with a copy of his novel in his hands.

“Found this by the tub. How far are you?”

“I started it.” I unwrap a rack of spareribs and set them on a baking sheet. I regret, for a moment, that I sold Oliver’s grill for a dime.

“You’re offended by the title. I knew you’d be offended.”

He sits at the table and props one foot on a chair. This makes me miss his childhood. I kiss the top of his head.

“No,” I say, “though I guess slut isn’t one of my favorite words.”

It doesn’t bother me that Colt’s book is called The Confessions of Slut Twenty-Three; nor does it bother me that Slut Twenty-Three, in the pages I’ve skimmed, physically resembles Vivian. If what he writes is taken from their lives, Vivian randomly demands sex in parking lots, makes Colt wear her hosiery, and runs a blow-job clinic in the smoking garden of a local bar.

I am not offended by his pedantic diagrams of sexual positions, or by the character named Mlle Fuck-You. It’s the shrill, smug voice he picked up in college that I can’t stand. His narrator, The-Man-in-Love-with-the-Slut, describes himself as “your average spoiled white kid from the suburbs.”

“You are not a ‘white kid from the suburbs,’ ” I want to tell him. “You’re from a small town nowhere near a city. You were raised to treat people decently. And your father and I never spoiled you.” But I know—I know, I know—that this is not an autobiography.

I believe Colt when he tells me that in certain circles he is famous. Once I suggested that those circles might be concentrated in Brooklyn, and my throat closed with guilt the moment I said it. Colt is my delight; he is my only child. For nine months I prayed for the healthy heart now beating under his shirt. As soon as I could hold him, heart and all, I sensed the futility of prayer. I knew that every time he was hurt it would be my fault.


They smoked a joint right before dinner while I picked green beans from the garden. Colt’s elbows are on the table. He tells us, several times, that he would love it if some backwoods library in the Deep South banned his book.

“Enough about you,” Vivian says.

“Okay. Tell Mom about your new business idea,” he says.

“We have this dog park near our building, and the people are ridiculous. They dress the dogs in little quilted jackets. They give them the same kinds of names they give their kids: Jordan, Mason, Hunter, Taylor.”

“So ridiculous,” Colt says.

“Anyway, there’s a multilingual school down the street from the park. I thought maybe people would be into a multilingual class for dogs. Not like they think the dog is going to speak, but so a dog can follow commands in three or four languages.”

“You’re kidding, right?”

“I am, but I’m not. I think if we charged $75 per session, we might convince some people it’s worth paying for. So that might be my project for the next six months.” The look they exchange tells me this joke has been broken in, and that every time she tells it, Colt is charmed.

“What about you, Mom?” he says. “What do you see yourself doing in the next six months?”

“Maybe some camping up in Acadia before it gets too cold.” Georgia and I have been planning this trip for months.

“But who would go with you?”

“Yeah, who would go with you?”

They give me a pitying look. They think I am alone, and they think they are invincible. Vivian has no visible reaction to Colt’s hand on the back of her neck. This is the smugness of having your lover beside you all the time. I want to tell her that being loved this much leaves no mark. If Colt rises from the table, she will look as lonely as I do.


Sometimes I wish Colt would find the whole thing abhorrent. Two women? Disgusting. His own mother? Disgusting. If he could back away from it, maybe I could tell him. But Colt and Viv would levitate with pleasure. They’d sit there thinking they’d finally figured me out: there’s Mom, Judith, clear as an egg wash, a classic closet case. Maybe she’s been waiting for Georgia her whole life.

Surely Colt remembers the traffic jam. A westbound lane on the Sagamore Bridge, a cup of rum-raisin ice cream in his hand, his head out the window to watch the Cape Cod Canal churning with rain, traces of zinc oxide on his nose. He was eleven. He asked his parents, “Have either of you ever been in love?”

Oliver had just given me opal earrings for my birthday, suffered a lobster dinner on my behalf.

“Of course, son,” he said, reaching back to tousle his hair.

I couldn’t stop wondering why Colt would ask us that.

“He asks why we can’t take vacation on a different planet. He asks why we can’t drink saltwater. I wouldn’t worry about this,” Oliver said.

We were in the yard, the grass freshly mowed, mosquitoes biting freely as dusk unraveled. It was a Saturday, the night Oliver was allowed to get drunk. Colt was at a friend’s house, observing marriages that were apparently stronger than mine.

“Give me a priss, kitty,” Oliver said. “Stop worrying.”

I worried even more after that.


I can see it now: Georgia in a souvenir T-shirt, a shade overweight, telling stories as if we’ve been married for years. The three of them teasing me for voting Republican. “I always knew there was a liberal in there somewhere,” Colt will say. They will need a little less from me, a little more from each other; I in turn will need a little more from all of them.

They’ll have cocktail hour while I drink club soda with lime. Georgia will mix vodka and grenadine, even though I’ve told her it’s tacky. She doesn’t mind being teased, and she doesn’t know how to be jealous, two of my favorite things about her. She indulges me when I need to talk about my married life. She knows how many buttons I had on my wedding dress. She knows that Oliver and I spent our wedding night at the Pioneer Hotel, with its misplaced neoclassical columns. The windows were jalousies, and there was only one towel in the bathroom. There was a folding screen, and I’d felt obliged to change behind it, even though we’d seen each other naked many times.


I call Vivian to the bathroom after my shower. She is pleased. This is the kind of thing daughters-in-law do: they enter intimate spaces unflinchingly.

“Take a look at this mole,” I tell her, pulling my robe away from my breast. “I swear I didn’t have it this morning.”

She excuses herself to get her glasses from her handbag.

“That’s not a mole, Judith. That’s a tick.”

“It looks like a mole.”

“That’s because he’s in there pretty deep.”

“Well, shit,” I say. “Can you get it out?”

First she tries tweezers, which I keep on a mirrored tray by the sink.

“This fucker’s really in there,” she says.

My eyes are watery, my head hot.

“Do you think I might already have Lyme disease?”

“Don’t be ridiculous,” she says, the first hint of a mother I’ve ever seen in her.

When Vivian worries the tweezers are making it worse, she asks Colt to bring matches. There are holes in the knees of her jeans, and her fingernails are painted gold. She has a scar on her arm from breaking a window when her father refused to give her his credit card. (She was, she has assured me, only twenty-two at the time.) This is the girl who holds a flame close to my skin.

When she finally gets the tick out without starting a fire, I offer her fifty dollars. “An investment in your multilingual dog business.”

“Just watch for a bull’s-eye around the bite. If you see a bull’s-eye, we’ll need to go to the doctor in the morning,” she says.


I lie awake with all the lights on, watching for a bull’s-eye.

When Georgia can’t sleep, I comb her hair. When I can’t sleep, she tells me about her childhood. She has three older brothers. In their yard they had a set of dolphin-shaped swings that appeared to be caught by their chains. The Connecticut River sluiced the edge of their property. The swings were still there when Georgia drove me past the house this summer, but the place was dingy and run-down. One of the panes in the front door was sealed with a piece of cardboard, and someone had spray-painted the word keep on the side of the house.

“Oh, well,” Georgia said. “Maybe some college students live there now.”

I could be that calm too, if I’d never had to iron an impatient man’s shirt or peel a soft-boiled egg for a screaming child. I am not the kind of woman who complains about the life she was meant to have: I was supposed to be handling shirts and eggs. My husband was supposed to be faithful.

In the years I was tending to Colt and Oliver, Georgia was serving her family as the quirky unmarried one. She drove her nieces and nephews to zoos. She bought them geodes and suspended prisms in their windows. If she ever meets my son, she will become his cheerful aunt. She’s already read his novel twice.

“You need to introduce me to Colt soon,” she said recently. I was driving her home from the doctor’s office. “It’s kind of insulting.”

“Could you turn the AC down? It’s freezing in here.”

“You think I’m too nice to give you a hard time about this, don’t you.”

“No,” I said, but I laughed.

“I’m serious, Judith. I’m not afraid to piss you off.”

“Don’t I know it,” I said, but I am almost never mad at Georgia. It was Oliver who drew anger out of me. Oliver, capricious and unapologetic, a man who kept me guessing every day of our marriage.

When we were first dating, I couldn’t decide how to greet him. He never learned how to embrace. He let you press your body into his chest, but his arms were limp and useless. His firm handshake was so brief you couldn’t tell if his skin was warm. That was me: choosing between one of his hands and two of his arms, weighing the trade-off, wanting more than I could get.
